markdownRemark.html:
I won’t pretend I am the biggest The Dillinger Escape Plan (TDEP) fan in the world. I have probably listened to roughly 80% of their discography. But I was enraptured by their unique style that sought to undo many of the comforts we have in conventional song-writing and musicianship.

Some years ago I was playing a video game called Bioshock in which you — the protagonist — crash land in the middle of the ocean in the opening chapter. The cause of your misfortune is not disclosed. The still floating, burning wreckage that was your plane is slowly sinking and so you are encourage to alight. Into the waters. Fortunately a tower in the middle of the ocean is within swimming distance, it is your only hope for survival. After dragging your apparently capable self out of the ocean waters your enter the tower. From here things get pretty crazy. An elevator takes you to an undersea city where the brightest scientific minds have created a safe haven for pushing the limits of what humanity can achieve. Unfettered by scruples they have pushed all fronts of scientific advancement. People can run faster, they are much stronger and they can shoot fireballs from their finger-tips (because why not!?). But not all is well in this undersea world called Rapture. Human greed and narcissism have won out. Self-improvement and self-glorification have led some in Rapture to aspire to totalitarian heights. Cue the track “When Acting As A Wave” from TDEP’s “Ire Works”.

Delving deeper still into the mysteries of Rapture I continued to listen to TDEP. A better musical match for the peculiar horrors in this underworld is a tall order. Like the denizens of rapture, TDEP is truly manic and schizophrenic. Their track “Lurch”, a song about a stalker reflecting on the object of his desire is as creepy as it sounds - “…your picture in my pocket I’m obsessed with you”.

There are songs that are truly moments of quiet clarity and none so more than, to my mind, than their track the title track from “Dissociation”. Tracks like these invite a more reflective and personal mode, albeit remaining true to the off-kilter sound TDEP work tirelessly to reproduce. Through a combination of two drum tracks coming in and out of the left and right sides of the stereo image I cannot think of a better depiction of being in two minds in music. Two narratives, not intended to co-exist but somehow co-existing regardless.
